fields.description:
When I want to commit some changes I have the option to "Push changes immediately to ..." but the problem is that is always pushing to the first sorted alphabetically remote. I'd like to have a dropdown menu to select a remote which will remain the default value for the fast push option. 

I attached a picture in which I have the option to push immediately to m75/master but I like to have the option to set to origin/master, option that will remain default until future changes.
fields.summary: Fast commit

fields.description:
When you look at the newest commit and mark a couple of lines in a diff, right click gives only the "Copy" option. To actually reverse only these lines, one has to click a button at the top of the current diff hunk.

The problem is if the hunk is large, it completely kills the usability of this solution as it's impractical to have to scroll up to find the button and then back down to where we were. The right-click menu should contain the "reverse lines" option as well.
fields.summary: Right-click menu should have "reverse lines" as well

fields.description:
I really don't like the changes made to the file status view, it's instantly become much less useable.  I strongly feel it should just be reverted back to how it used to be.  If that option won't be considered, here are some more detailed points with my issues with the changes:

1. Files are now listed with their paths at the start, this means the most important part, the file name itself, is now at the far right, and not aligned nicely  with any of the other files names.  This makes it much harder to quickly glance down the list to spot file names.

2. I used to be able to select a number of files and drag them to the staging area together to stage them.  You can no longer do this, meaning you have to stage each one individually (or, at least I can see no other way to do it - and I've looked quite hard).  The staged files area isn't even shown now until a file is staged.

3. There used to be a clear and consistent division on the page between stages and unstated files.  Now they're all just in one long list, which is a lot less useful.  They are separated in the list, but where that separation is changes.

4. The commit options are now in a drop-down at the right of the new commit box, this means you a) can't easily see what options are selected, and b) have to click the drop-down to expand it for each option you want to change.  This is less usable than before, and also isn't a very standard user experience.

5. Oh, maybe I can click the "Commit" button at the to pro get the previous commit screen back - nope, that just expands the commit at the bottom, adding more non-standard user experience, and making the button almost completely pointless.

I hate to sound so negative, but I really think the changes are a step backwards.  They remove functionality, make other functionality worse, and all I can see that they add is a slightly quicker method for committing changes (unless you want to set any commit options).
fields.summary: revert the changes to the 'File Status'

fields.description: When you perform Ignore action on any file directly from GUI it places the rule to .gitignore_global file instead of repository's .gitignore file.
fields.summary: Ignore action places the rule to .gitignore_global instead of repository .gitignore

fields.description:
Hi :)

If I select a number of committed changes only then diff-view is working fine. But if I include 'Uncommitted changes' too then diff-view is stuck on the last shown diff. Please see attachment, thanks.

Cheers!
fields.summary: Displaying all changes between ? and working copy doesn't work

fields.description: In the new interface it's not possible to revert deletion of a file. There is a "Reset to commit" option but it's grayed out.
fields.summary: No way to revert a file

fields.description:
The current hgflow version in SourceTree is 0.9.4.

It should be upgraded to the latest hgflow version 0.9.7 to use .hgflow configuration file
fields.summary: Upgrade hgflow version to the latest 0.9.7

fields.description:
I have an extensive list of branches, both local and remote. In the current version of SourceTree, when I want to know if a local branch is tracking a remote one, I have to right click the branch, and see whether a remote branch is checked under "Track Remote Branch".

It would be very useful if there was a visual indication in the branch list if that branch tracks a remote branch. For me personally, it is not necessary to indicate which remote branch is tracked (that can still be checked in the context menu).

This is useful because often you have to handle tracking branches with more care (look out for rebases and whatnot).
fields.summary: Indicate branches that track remote branches

fields.description:
Select a line in hunk and try to stage it alone using "Stage lines" button.
A file polling update happens usually the moment between you select the line and you try to click the button, which turns into the "Stage hunk".

I've accidentally staged some hunks like this already. It's been better in the previous version where these were two separate buttons, but the core issue is 
you should fix this pointless file polling which resets all the selection I made.

Use kqueue file watch or something.
fields.summary: Mindless polling updates reset selection info

fields.description:
h4.Steps to reproduce
# Create 10 branches
# Click on Push action
The popup Push action window not able to show all the branches. Need to scroll up/down.
# Resize the window to show all the branches
# Selecting the checkbox "Select All" does not work for some branches
fields.summary: "Select All" checkbox does not work on Push action

fields.description:
When I developing an iOS project with Xcode, I have a project.pbxproj at this path :
NameOfProject.xcodeproj/project.pbxproj

The file is in the list of changed files so I can stage and commit it but i cannot see any changements made to it. The Diff view shows nothing.
fields.summary: Cannot see Diff of .pbxproj files

fields.description:
After amending a commit, the amend option remains checked. This is not immediately obvious as the checkbox has now been hidden under a features submenu. This makes it really easy to accidentally amend an existing commit if the developer forgets to manually find and uncheck this option after the last commit.

I think two reasonable approaches that could address this:
1. Make the amend checkbox state clear after a commit. So by default, the developer needs to re-check this every time they want to re-amend an existing commit
2. Or, make it clearly visible somewhere on the main commit screen that the amend option is active. E.g., perhaps change the "Commit" button label to "Amend", or maybe show some type of UI overlay saying Amend mode is active.

This issue is somewhat related to SRCTREE-2238 and SRCTREE-2258.
fields.summary: Amend commit checkbox state remains checked after commit

fields.description: A great feature that I use all the time is the ability of fixing a bug and then add it to the comments (draft) to later on do a commit. In the previous version the comment was being persisted even if you close the application and open it again, but since the latest version the comments are being wiped if you close the app.
fields.summary: Comments are not being saved

fields.description:
1. on the command line, check out a branch, but don't name it

git checkout origin/<sometopicbranch>

RESULT:

Note: checking out 'origin/<sometopicbranch>'.
You are in 'detached HEAD' state. You can look around, make experimental
changes and commit them, and you can discard any commits you make in this state without impacting any branches by performing another checkout.

If you want to create a new branch to retain commits you create, you may
do so (now or later) by using -b with the checkout command again. Example:
  git checkout -b new_branch_name
HEAD is now at 605262c... formatting changes

2. Launch sourcetree from command line. Make sure the view setting is set to "current branch" and not all branches. 



An error message will pop up "'git log' failed with code 128:'fatal: bad revision '(detached from origin/<sometopicbranch>)'"


This issue is similar to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1292
fields.summary: git log error when trying to list changes of an unnamed branch

fields.description: I always keep the "Use the Staging Area" option off, but since updating to 1.9.2, I find that I constantly have to go back into the options and un-check this  box as the "staging area" keeps coming back to life.  In fact, at one point, I would uncheck the box and it would immediately re-check itself, forcing me to use the staging area.  I had to restart SourceTree to make the selection stick.  I have not yet found a cause or a sequence of events that cause the setting to be reset but I will update this issue if I can figure out how to recreate it.
fields.summary: "Use the Staging Area" preference keeps getting reset

fields.description: What it says on the tin: when I try to start up SourceTree, it crashes and I receive a dialog box indicating the same. I am attaching the crash log saved to My computer. Do let Me know if I can provide any additional information.
fields.summary: Sourcetree Crashes on Startup

fields.description:
Source tree keeps seeing lines which haven't changed as being changed (see screenshot)

It's making the commits very messy

There's nothing special to re-create. I've not even edited those lines once, it just seems think they're different.

Thanks,

DanC
fields.summary: Source Tree thinks blank lines have changes and commits them

fields.description:
I have the "Log" view open and choose "Show only Pending". Only pending files are displayed. I switch to "File Status" view and select "Show only All Files" and all files are displayed. I switch back to "Log" view and all files are displayed, but the pull down says "Show only Pending".  If I change the selection, the file list changes, too. If I switch back to "File Status" the file list there has changed, too but the pop-up still says "All Files".

It seems both views share the same file list and even though each view supports a different file list configuration ("Show only" and "Sort by"), the file list is not updated when switching between views. This is confusing, as I'd like to show different files in those two views.
fields.summary: File List not updated when switching between File Status and Log view
Make merge dialog the same as Windows, only exposing --no-ff option

fields.description:
When staging selected lines, sometimes the UI will update itself automatically, losing the line selection.
This also happened in older versions but was annoying at most. With the new UI however, the 'stage lines' button will change into 'stage hunk'. So instead of staging lines I now accidentally stage the whole hunk, which also loses me the careful selection of lines I might have already staged.
fields.summary: re-separate buttons for staging/discarding lines/hunks

fields.description:
1) Clone https://github.com/joyent/node.git
2) Open this repo in SourceTree
3) Scroll down to the first commit.

See the screenshot. There shouldn't be anything in the structure going beyond the oldest commit.

This problem has been showing up for a long time.
fields.summary: Some commits have parents going beyond the initial commit in the tree view for some repositories

fields.description:
When i try to pull via SourceTree from a remote repository remote branches are always empty at first. I can retrieve remote branches by pressing 'refresh'. But i have to do this every time i launch this dialog. Even if i close and immediately open it again. I've compared this with my other MacBook and a MacBook of my colleague. Both installed SourceTree, having (almost) the same git-config. They do not have this problem. I removed and reinstalled SourceTree (even deleting files under ~/Library/Application Support) and it didn't solve the problem. After pressing 'refresh' remote branches are available for this moment. I also can see a loading spinner icon in the drop down menu when i open the pull dialog but there are not any results. Only after manually refreshing them.

The only difference between this Mac I'm having this issue and my second one is that I installed a plain SourceTree app on this one while I had the AppStore version installed on the second one before.

The last update didn't fix this issue. The issue occurs in every repository every time. It doesn't occur on the other Macs where the same repositories are used.

If necessary I can provide further details.
fields.summary: Remote Branches to Pull Are Always Empty

fields.description:
I have enabled the option to automatically push new commits to the remote repositories.

When I have no network connectivity and trigger a commit, forgetting to uncheck the "push to remote" option, I get an error message that the push failed. At the same time, my working directory is clean, but I cannot see the commit I just triggered in the list.

After restarting SourceTree, the commit appears in the list.

This behavior can be reproduced quite simply: disconnect your machine from the network, and trigger a commit with "push to remote" enabled.

Best regards!
fields.summary: Commits missing after automatic push to remote failed

fields.description:
Since upgrading to 1.9.2, the majority of my commits hang. The UI still looks generally responsive (indeterminate progress bar is animating), but I can't cancel the commit, quit ST, etc. I have to force quit. Then the next commit usually works after restart. Usually one commit will work, then a commit soon after will cause the hang.

See attached ss for example of where the hang occurs.

I don't believe I ever experienced this issue previously.
fields.summary: Majority of commits hang

fields.description: When clicked on Settings -> Remotes -> Add the focus is on "Remote name". When I press <tab> I expect focus move to "URL / path", but it doesn't happen.
fields.summary: Invalid focus in remote management

fields.description: We have repositories (that best practices not-withstanding) require usernames of the format first initial, last name (i.e. bsmith). The changes to 1.9.x forced an email address to the username, and if it didn't exist wouldn't allow you to commit. In 1.9.2, the email address was allowed to be optional (it can be empty), but that results in a commit username "bsmith <(null)>" rather than just bsmith. If an email address is not included, the resulting field should just be the username that is defined, and it shouldn't keep prompting for the email.  Please consider restoring the pre-1.9 functionality, which was more accommodating - we can't use 1.9.x in our repositories at the moment.
fields.summary: Empty email address uses committer "username <(null)>" instead of just "username" (stores "(null)" as email address)

fields.description:
I did a merge from a remote branch (master) into my feature branch.  In my branch, I had modified a certain file.  In the remote (master) branch, the file had been deleted.

This resulted in a conflict, but the only way to resolve this conflict is to either accept the deletion or re-add the file with my changes.

The Launch External Merge tool option created all the files for a 3-way DIFF, except "LOCAL" was empty and for some reason that caused SourceTree to not launch the external merge tool.  So, that option effectively does nothing.

The "Resolve Using Theirs" option kept my version of the file.  I didn't try "Resolve Using Mine".

It appears that SourceTree doesn't know how to handle conficts due to file deletes.  It would be nice if the UI could at least indicated "This file was deleted".  I had to drop to the CLI to query the git status to even find out why it was conflicted.
fields.summary: Resolve Conflict actions fail when the conflict is due to remote file delete

fields.description:
I have a conflicted file.  I right-click on the file and select "Resolve Conflict -> Launch External Merge Tool". When I select the option, SourceTree creates 4 files: BACKUP, BASE, LOCAL, REMOTE.

LOCAL is empty and the merge tool isn't launched.

After some investigating using the command line, the reason that the file is conflicted is that the remote file was DELETED while I made a change to the same file.  The conflict could only be resolved by either keeping my changes or accepting the delete.  I tried to resolve using "Resolve using theirs", but that just kept the original file without the delete.

I'm not sure how that should be handled, but it appears that SourceTree doesn't know how to handle conflicts with deleted files.  It doesn't even show up in the UI to indicate the conflict is due to a remote file delete.
fields.summary: Resolve Conflicts doesn't work if the remote file was deleted

fields.description:
SourceTree seems to crash whenever the underlying network environment changes for the system.
When I move from my home+VPN to my office network and back ->> If i go back to the SourceTree app which is already running - it crashes. 

I am attaching some crash logs. I have lots of them :)
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes on Network changes

fields.description: It was nice to have some separation (whitespace/padding) between the display of stageed & unstaged files. The current view makes it more difficult to tell at a glance what is staged because the recent updates removed this whitespace.
fields.summary: Put spacing back between staged and unstaged area

fields.description:
After clicking the "select all" checkbox to stage unstaged files, a "wait spinner" appears to the right of the checkbox and never goes away. The unstaged files remain unchecked. If I quit and restart the app, the formerly unstaged files now show as being staged.

This problem has occurred multiple times - but not every time, so I can't provide a definitive way to replicate the problem. I will update this issue if I can find a way to reproduce the problem reliably.
fields.summary: "Select all" checkbox hangs

fields.description:
If a user perform a commit before checking the pull status, the changes in the commit might have conflict with the new updates in the repository server.

It would be better if SourceTree can auto detect the pull status when the user is performing commit and show a warning that there will be a conflict between the changes in the commit and the new updates in the repository server.
fields.summary: Auto detect pull state on commit action

fields.description:
I'm finding the new dynamically moving checkbox staging area to be frustrating, counter productive and a real slow down in efficiency.

E.g, I click something to add, then move mouse to click the next file i've already spotted and it moves from its position (due to the first file moving up and the order of files changing). 
I end up clicking the file that was shifted to its place and it gets added instead, I then usually have to go and un-click it as i did not want to stage that file or at least lookup and double check what it was to see if i did need to add it.

It's too much disruptive movement and trying to click moving targets is a UX experience best left in experimental flash web sites from the early 2000s. Not otherwise excellent source control software.

I'm aware i can turn the "staging area" mode off, but this does not change what is a really poor experience. The previous two separate panes for staged and un-stagged files was more clearer and not in the slightest a maddening shooting gallery
fields.summary: Stage files with checkboxes: moving targets = bad experience

fields.description:
When the "Push to default/origin remote when comitting" option is checked and there isn't any remote repo in the bookmark, then it is impossible to commit because the "Push changes immediately to (null)/develop" checkbox is always checked. The "commit" button does not work anymore - I can click it, but no action is taken.

Please see the images for the reference.

http://glui.me/?i=kl6pn8gjpkh42x8/2014-05-09_at_08.21.png/

http://glui.me/?i=oyj5m3tpfjun80s/2014-05-09_at_08.22.png/
fields.summary: Pushing to non-existing remote

fields.description:
In pre-1.9 versions the commit message was being remembered even after restart of SourceTree.

Now in 1.9 it is wiped out upon restart. This is not cool when you typed quite some sentences during your dev day :(
fields.summary: Commit message is not remembered after restart

fields.description:
After creating a local repository, without any remotes, the commit pane displays the (disabled) option "Push changes immediately to (null)/master".

That could be misleading to the user, who might assume that something has gone wrong (a not unreasonable assumption when you see the word "null" in  the user interface). A better solution would just be to hide the option completely if no remote is available.

I've only tested this on 1.9.1 as I haven't updated to 1.9.2 yet, but I don't see any mention of a fix for it, so I assume it's present there too.
fields.summary: (null) placeholder in Commit pane when no remote has been added

fields.description: After clicking "Reset" a window opens listing the uncomitted files.  To the left of the file name is a check box but it is squished horizontally so that it is nearly unusable.  The ability to move the separator bar (between the file list on the left and the differences on the right) was not working.  I resized the window and then the separator bar would work so that I could access the check boxes.  Once it was working it wasn't possible to move the separator bar back to the left far enough to repeat the initial view; the movement was limited.  But that limit wasn't being applied upon opening the window.
fields.summary: "Squished" check-boxes in file list window

fields.description:
First of all, it seems some git pull --rebase I did from CLI left the repo in some invalid state at some point.

Then I opened up sourcetree and moved my latest changes to the index, thinking that I probably just forgot to commit the previous stuff as it looked like it was still in index.

I clicked the big commit button, and got a dialog saying I've got a partial rebase or something going on in the repo, thinking that ok, this is something I should probably fix I clicked on "Abort" thinking it means "stop whatever is going on right now and let me fix it"

Apparently instead of "abort" the button's real meaning was "CLICK ME AND I WILL DESTROY ALL YOUR WORK, MWAHAHAHA!" as it removed the changes I had just added to the index, from the index AND didn't restore them to the working copy either.

I'm lucky that my IDE can keep history of changes that are applied even outside the IDE so I was able to recover from this.

Either way, it's not cool to destroy people's work like that.
fields.summary: "Abort rebase" -button actually means "Destroy all my changes please"

fields.description: If i select in the preferences the "Push to default/origin remote when commiting" option, and i have a git repository without any remotes. I try to commit the changes, but the commit button does not work. I think you should check if there are any remotes and if don't you should ignore the push phase, and just commit the changes. You could also indicate this in the "Push changes immdediately to (null)/master. By the way this option is disabled by default if you don't have a remote, and the checkmark is selected, so i can not deselect it. Please consider these suggestions, thanks.
fields.summary: Can not commit if i select push to default/origin option and there is no remote.

fields.description:
In old versions of Sourcetree it was possible
Now i can not do it

Thanks
fields.summary: Cannot add folder with all content to ignore list

fields.description:
Currently, a log of X commit messages are preserved, so it's easy to use as template for new message. 

When you work a lot in one project, that log reflects all recent work for that project. However, going back to another project, you no longer see the old commits done for that particular project.

If commit message logs are preserved per project, then it also become easy to see the work that was done recently.
fields.summary: Preserve commit messages log per project (last 25-30 commits)

fields.description: I tried diffing a .png file with external diff, which is FileMerge. FileMerge reported an error "not an ascii file". After that I returned to SourceTree and right clicked the same file (in commit changed files list) at which point SourceTree didn't respond. The situation was fixed when FileMerge was killed.
fields.summary: Hang when trying to use external diff (FileMerge) to diff image file

fields.description:
The new diff panel in 1.9.x no longer indicates when a file has changed permissions.  Prior to 1.9 the old and new permissions were displayed, even when the file contents were otherwise unchanged.  I am attaching screen shots of the diff view of such a file in both 1.8.1 and 1.9.2 to illustrate the difference.

(The context is that I use Microsoft's git-tf utility to access a code base stored on a TFS server which does not retain Unix file permissions, so when I pull a script file it often has its execute permission bit stripped in the commit but has no other changes.)
fields.summary: Diff view no longer indicates change in file permissions

fields.description: The Commit button (in the bottom right corner) does not work newly created repos. It is still working for repos that were created prior to 1.9.2.  However, now when creating a new repo, adding a file to it, and trying to commit, clicking on the Commit button (which is active) does nothing.  Files can be committed to the Git repo via the command line.
fields.summary: Commit Button Not Working

fields.description: There is no way to change the "lines of context" scope when looking at differences from the Search view.  In the Log view, I can adjust the difference window to see more or less lines around the differences but that button for that setting is missing in the Search view since the UI was updated in version 1.9.0
fields.summary: No way to adjust "lines of context" in search view

fields.description:
I'm using a .git file in the root of my project to store the repository elsewhere, as described here:
http://stackoverflow.com/a/8603156/53537
Unfortunately, sourcetree appears not to understand the .git file (which contains *gitdir: ../repos/bgg.git*), which means that when I perform git actions (git add, for example) Sourcetree doesn't recognize them until I manually refresh. If you are monitoring a directory for changes, and updating based on that, also monitoring the repo as specified in the .git file would probably solve this issue.
This may be related to SRCTREE-1265, but is different, and possibly solvable, because it does not involve a symlink, but rather uses a feature of git to specify the repository location.
fields.summary: Auto refresh fails for git when repo is stored outside the project directory

fields.description:
Before going into the commit screen, mark some files for staging.
Now press the commit button to go to the commit screen.
The commit button (at the right bottom of the screen) is disabled though files are marked.
If you unmark a file and re-mark it, the button will become enabled.

It seems when the screen is initialized - there's no check if any file is already marked...
fields.summary: Commit button is disabled though files are marked for commit

fields.description:
h5. Summary
When staging files for a commit with a filter (e.g. "NLM_" for files starting with prefix "NLM_"), the select all files toggle doesn't respect the filter.

h5. Steps to Reproduce
# Change a couple files
# Enter a file so that only some of those files are shown in unstaged files list
# Click "Unstage Files" checkbox
# Clear Filter
See attached screen recording for STRs in action.

h5. Expected Outcome
Only the files shown while filter enabled are staged.

h5. Actual Outcome
All files are staged.
fields.summary: Select All Files in Commit Window Doesn't Respect Filter

fields.description: Using the spacebar to select and deselect files works. However, the way it moves the file between "staged" and "unstaged" makes a keyboard based workflow almost worthless. One can't simply arrow between the files and check or uncheck the ones he/she want because the focus keeps shifting to the bottom or the top of the screen.
fields.summary: Spacebar Selection/Deselection Keeps Shifting Focus for Tree View

fields.description:
- Use Actions/Create Patch... on any working copy file(s)
- Save the patch file somewhere (e.g. "Desktop/test.diff")
- Delete the test.diff file using Finder
- Try to empty the Trash

Seems SourceTree still has an open handle on the diff file, so it can't be permanently deleted until the app quits.
fields.summary: Patch files not fully released after creating - prevents trash from emptying

fields.description:
Prior to 1.9.x version modified files under 'File Status' tab were displayed with filename only. Currently whole path is displayed which makes it harder to identify what file was changed.

My suggestion is to add the display style of modified files as an option in preferences of the app.
fields.summary: Display style of modified files under 'File Status' tab

fields.description:
The new grouped table view is an endless source of confusion and mistakes. The old system was so well done. I drag an item to the top table and I can clearly see what's happening. In the new version, SourceTree is always trying to keep something selected and it is *always* the wrong thing. I am constantly confused about what I am looking at. Because the table changes every time I check something, my mouse is always in the wrong place. I just accidentally staged everything because things are always moving around. This is just poorly done. It's not even a question of not liking change. This is just not very well done. But I should come with solutions, not problems, right?

Go back to two table views that are in a split view so that they don't change sizes. When I check un-staged, it goes to staged but its tableview does not resize. The next un-staged item would move up but the group header does not move. Importantly, the item that *was* selected, goes to staged and *stays* selected so the thing that I was looking at does *not* change. Just as important, the table view header does not move so I don't accidentally stage/un-staged everything.

I am a big fan of SourceTree but even filing this issue was painfully difficult. I hope that some usability improvements come soon. Overall, the 1.9 release is quite good but this stage/un-staged table is killing me.
fields.summary: Grouped (staged/un-staged) table view creates serious usability problems

fields.description:
1. open Sourcetree and click on a previous commit.  Note that the bottom two panes are split with the committed-files list (on the left) getting about 20% of the space, and the right-bottom file-diff pane getting about 80% (see attached screenshot).

2. adjust the split so that the panes get 50% each.

3. quit and reopen Sourcetree

4. note that the split is back to the way it was before, 20/80.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not save the split position between the bottom two panes in the history view

fields.description: Staging number of files at once can lead to spinning wheel shown and view is not refreshed. Staging another file or switch between the views (Cmd + 1, Cmd + 2 etc) sometimes fixes the situation.
fields.summary: Staging bunch of files doesn't refresh the view.

fields.description:
1. If different submodules are specified for the different branches of the same project and some of them are cloned into same local folders, it's almost impossible to switch between branches.
SourceTree reports that "cannot remove folder because it's not empty", looses track of submodule, shows infinite number of dialogs that "repository is missing" and so on.
Meanwhile, Tower just switches branches and get all submodules for the branch without that hysteria, so it's possible to implement.
2. It would be great to indicate when you in detached head, because it's quite easy to loose your changes.

Guys, I don't quite sure whether it is Bug or New Feature, so please set proper issue type. Also, I marked it as Critical as switching between branches which have different set of submodules is an everyday operation for us, and all my team members are quite tired with that "submodules nightmare".
fields.summary: Improve support of submodules in SourceTree

fields.description:
When there is no username or email set for the repository or global config, SourceTree 1.9.1 force user to have non-empty email field in the commit dialog.

Is it possible to relax this requirement?
fields.summary: Allow empty email on commit action when there is no username or email set

fields.description:
I want to use the Page Up and Page Down keys to scroll the diff pane, a very standard use of the Page Up and Page Down keys. But the keys do not scroll the pane.

REPRO:
1. Make many changes to a file under source control.
2. View the diff in SourceTree (1.9.1). View 100 lines. More content than can be seen on the page.
3. Give focus to the diff pane of SourceTree by clicking in the pane.
4. Press Page Up, Page Down, Home, and End keys.

EXPECTED:
 - Diff pane should scroll according to what key you press.

ACTUAL:
 - Diff pane does not scroll.

NOTE:
The keys DO work to scroll the commits tree pane. Not the diff pane, however.
fields.summary: Cannot use PageUp/PageDown or Home/End to scroll code diffs.

fields.description: Viewing a commit in log view will only show the new name of the files for renamed files.  In order to see the previous file name, one must "Log Selected" and then select "Follow renamed files".  That is a lot of steps for information that could easily appear in the initial UI.  I think SRCTREE-WIN has this UI feature.
fields.summary: Show old file name of renamed file in commit view of log view

fields.description: The new version does not honor my setting to not use the staging area.  If I set the preference to not use the staging area, once I add a file to my git repository, the staging area is turned back on and I can't change the preference again until the files have been committed.
fields.summary: "Use the staging area" setting is not honored when adding a file.

fields.description:
Drag-and-drop for elements into staging area was replaced by check boxes.
First variant was very useful.
fields.summary: Drag-and-drop for staging area

fields.description:
Since I upgraded from 1.8.1, the hosted repositories browser shows only 25 repositories for every stash project.
All repositories after the 25th are not visible in the list and do not show up when using the search function.

I am adding repositories using their url as a workaround for now.
fields.summary: Hosted repositories browser is limited to the first 25 repositories in a stash project

fields.description: Whenever a single file is selected and spacebar is pressed, the staged/unstaged checkbox doesn't change.
fields.summary: Using spacebar to stage/unstage files doesn't work correctly

fields.description:
When selecting 3 files for example, which are all checked, pressing spacebar with this selection unchecks 2 files, but the last selected file remains in the state it was prior to pressing spacebar. This happens in multiple views.

To reproduce:
Select bottom source file. 
Hold shift, and press up twice whilst holding.
Press spacebar.

Same can be done for selecting top file, and going downwards.
fields.summary: Using spacebar to stage/unstage multiple files always leaves last selected file unaltered

fields.description:
Good morning everybody, how you doing? 

I just upgraded SourceTree for Mac up to 1.9.1 version. 
Then I added my Github account and noticed one thing, that in the "Hosted Repositories" were all kind of repos, which I once "Forked", "Contributed",  "Starred" or even "Opened an Issue" and list got little messy (see attached image bellow).

And now i'm not even interested in all that repositories. So it would be nice, (important I would say), to add at least a checkbox, when adding accounts, saying that "I want to display ONLY my repositories", which I created myself ( or forked ).

So, I hope, I was my request was understandable and waiting for your replay guys!

Thanks!
fields.summary: Display only "my repositories" from Github.

fields.description: I recently upgraded to SourceTree 1.9.1. It no longer has the column view of the working copy. Everything is flat. Please restore the option to have the column view of the working copy. Sometimes, it is much easier to add files for commits, by adding the enclosing folder, instead of having to select via checkboxes. It can be very confusing to have to look through a long list of checkboxes, if a lot of items need to be added at once.
fields.summary: Restore Column View

fields.description: If my file has a really long name (longer than the width of the screen) and I select the file in unstaged or staged files section, that sections becomes reduced to nothing and the diff area gets fully expanded. This makes it impossible to select other files either staged or not staged. It's impossible to resize that area.
fields.summary: Long filenames make it impossible to see staged and unstaged files

fields.description:
The changes made to the UI/UX of the 1.9 are controversial and make poor UX for many SourceTree users, especially those who are more proficient with git and prefer the git workflow over the Mercurial one.

Please consider brining back:

- Tree view
- Separate the path/filename
- The stage window
- Drag & drop support
fields.summary: Please consider brining back (some) pre 1.9 UI/UX

fields.description:
Before going into the commit screen, mark some files for staging.
Now press the commit button to go to the commit screen.
The commit button (at the right bottom of the screen) is disabled though files are marked.
If you unmark a file and re-mark it, the button will become enabled.

It seems when the screen is initialized - there's no check if any file is already marked...
fields.summary: Commit button is disabled though files are marked for commit

fields.description: Most of the time you don't need the full path to the file.  Can you add a toggle to hide the full path and only show the file name.
fields.summary: Make the path on staging area toggle

fields.description: The latest SourceTree update (1.9.1) turned on the Staging Area and I can no longer turn it off in Preferences / Git / Use the staging area. Clicking the checkbox just turns it back on again.
fields.summary: Cannot turn of staging area

fields.description:
C'mon, what's with all these regressions? This is horrible.

I can't drag files from working copy to index anymore... I have to click each one and do them manually or right click on them...
fields.summary: Can't drag and drop files from working copy to index

fields.description: When I ignore or remove or do any action to an item, I shouldn't have to refresh (command R) to get an updated view... that's ridiculous.
fields.summary: Refresh view after action

fields.description:
You have a typo in your release notes :P

Fix for occasional white line rendering *artefacts* between red/green background in diff when scrolling slowly
fields.summary: I found a bug in your release notes

fields.description:
With 1.9.x, the log view is only a list, we lost the tree view.

Sometimes, especially when there are hundreds modifications, the tree view is more productive than the list view; it is the classical flat versus hierarchical views, both are useful.

Having the full path and sort choices is nice, but is no substitute for the hierarchical view.
fields.summary: Bring back the tree sub-view of Log View

fields.description: Please consider removing the horizontal lines between each file name in the list of changed files.  I find them distracting myself, and it's generally argued (e.g., Tufte) that such lines are unneeded, add clutter, and draw attention away from information.
fields.summary: too many horizontal lines in the list of files

fields.description: Please make the column with line numbers optional, probably by preference.  At least for me, it grabs a lot of visual attention in the new interface design and is rarely the first place one wants to look.  It is also mostly redundant with the note above the hunk.  It would help somewhat to move it over to the right side, rather than being so central, but I think the view would be cleaner and faster to understand if it was gone when not needed.
fields.summary: Make the line numbers column optional

fields.description:
I am a user of BitBucket and normally clone repositories by listing them using the earth icon under the 'Clone Repository' section of the bookmarks. The listings are working correctly, I can see all of the repositories I am following on BitBucket.

When clicking a repository (to select it and create a new bookmark), I select the item and either double click or click 'Ok'. It returns me to the screen without filling out the repository details.

Additionally, if I right click any of the lists to try and copy the clone URLs this feature does not work either despite saying it has been done.
fields.summary: Clone Repository feature not working on latest version (1.9.0)

fields.description:
I'm amazed this one did make it through the Atlassian internal Q&A review: The keyboard shortcuts, like Cmd-Shift-C for "Commit staged changes" and Cmd-Option-C for "Commit individual file" (bypassing the index) are defunct in 1.9. This is really annoying, since me (and probably others) totally rely on the keyboard for making the changes.

Just compare these functions in 1.8 and 1.9 and you will see that they act very, very differently. Cmd-Option-C is not there at all, I believe, in 1.9.

Anyone else also seeing this?
fields.summary: Please bring back the "Commit mode: Selected Files" option

fields.description:
I have a commit where only an image has changed. 

When clicking on the commit the side-by-side diff is shown. That works as expected. When I click on *Before* and then back to *Side-by-side*, I only get the image with the *After* caption above it. See screenshot.
fields.summary: Binary side-by-side comparison does not work when coming from After comparison

fields.description:
I was updating my vendor jQuery files from 2.1.1-rc2 to 2.1.1. I had 3 files (jquery.js, jquery.min.js, jquery.min.map) from the 2.1.1-rc2 version. I downloaded all 3 files from the just-released 2.1.1 version and saved over those files. Then, I went to the console and did `git mv jquery-2.1.1-rc2 jquery-2.1.1`; then I modified the path in the HTML file.

Now, When I go to SourceTree, I see what's on the screenshots. Clicking on any of the checkboxes causes the spinner to appear and it gets stuck in this way forever, nothing gets added to index. Clicking on another commit & back goes to the previous view without any spinner or checkbox marked. There is no increased CPU usage, hang or anything like that, it just doesn't do what it's supposed to.

I had to add those files manually via `git add`. Before doing that, `git status` reported the following:

$ git status
On branch develop
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/develop'.

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)

	modified:   ../index-template.html
	renamed:    jquery-2.1.1-rc2/jquery.js -> jquery-2.1.1/jquery.js
	renamed:    jquery-2.1.1-rc2/jquery.min.js -> jquery-2.1.1/jquery.min.js
	renamed:    jquery-2.1.1-rc2/jquery.min.map -> jquery-2.1.1/jquery.min.map

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

	modified:   jquery-2.1.1/jquery.js
	modified:   jquery-2.1.1/jquery.min.js
	modified:   jquery-2.1.1/jquery.min.map
fields.summary: Cannot stage files

fields.description:
Please add a feature of viewing a version of a file, which precedes the selected commit. This could be added as an item in the following context menu:
http://screencast.com/t/zJTLl5UET95w
fields.summary: Open preceding version

fields.description:
This is an expected extension to 
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-2279
fields.summary: Moving branches from folder to folder

fields.description:
A branch named like "a/b" is presented as a branch "b" in a folder "a" by SourceTree, which is good. However the possibility to rename the folder is obviously lacking. 

This would be a very useful feature allowing batch renaming of grouped branches.
fields.summary: Rename branch folders

fields.description:
The new user experience concept of the Working Copy view in SourceTree v1.9 changed a lot for everyone being used to the "drag&drop" concept. But there is one specific thing extremely missing in this new view:
The *Treeview for files*.

In former releases you could at the top decide whether to display the files in flat or in tree view. Why has this functionality disappeared? When you now switch to see all files (not just pending) in a large project, you have _no clue_ where you are inside your folder structure. 
Additionally, displaying always the *full path* is *unnecessary*. In deep folder structures, the view will be overloaded. The user should be able to choose.

I would be very glad to see these important features in the first hotfix - otherwise I will be forced to downgrade to version 1.8 ......
fields.summary: File-Treeview in Working Copy view of version 1.9

fields.description:
All hunks are merged into one view and grey divide is not enough. I provided 2 screenshots that can help to understand the issue.

After the latest updated it starts to hard to understand if the line of code is in this hunk or it already belongs to another one. The previous division was much better.

I propose to use the same divide between hunks of two different files and between hunks of one file. In first case device should be a bit wider.
fields.summary: Return back clear divide between each hunk in changes view

fields.description:
I have a large monitor, so there's a lot of space on the toolbar above the pending changes file list and the diffs.

I loved being able to instantly switch between show/ignore whitespace, change the lines of context, show only conflicts or pending etc.

Now not only do I have to click twice to set those options, but I can't instantly see what they are currently set to! E.g. I might not realise I'm ignoring white space, and end up committing some Python code that breaks because of the indentation.

There's also now three styles of buttons that contain additional options. There's one with text in a rounded button that does show the selected value for multiple options (in a single button), then there's a gear box in a square button (no idea what it does until you click on it, that's bad), and then there's "..." (also no idea what it does until you click on it).

I much preferred the way 1.8 would display as many options as could fit, so I could change them instantly with one click, but it was acceptable that when space ran out they collapsed into list options showing the current value and allowing you to select others.

But the new style seems to offer no improvement at all, unless you really dislike clutter and prefer available options to be hidden away under ambiguous "..." and gear box icon menus.
fields.summary: Don't bury view and stage/unstage options in menus

fields.description:
After I have committed with a message
I expect it to be on top of history
But if that message is already in history
It stays at the same location instead of being moved to the top
fields.summary: Not updating commit message history

fields.description:
I find it a bit jarring when I click on commit in the toolbar and a) my log disappears; b) pending changes and diffs move up and take up the whole screen; c) the commit message is all the way at the bottom of the screen.

I use SourceTree with as much vertical space as possible, so it's a long way to move the mouse from commit button to commit message field and then from individual pending files and hunks (all at at the top) to the commit message window and back again.

Especially when viewing only a small set of changes, there's just a huge amount of white space separating the files/diffs and commit message field.

I'd like to see the commit message field always at the top when "uncommitted changes" is selected, above the pending files/diffs so it's super easy to switch focus between staging hunks and files and composing the message.

I'd also like to see the log view retained when committing from there. It can be useful to switch back and forth between old commits and uncommitted changes to compose a message. If I wanted to commit with maximum space for diffs, I'd just do it directly from the working copy view.

This would also mean you could simply use the entire "working copy" view as-is in the bottom half of the window when "uncommitted changes" is selected in the log view. With the single line commit message already visible, you wouldn't even need to go and click commit on the toolbar.
fields.summary: Move commit message to top of commit window.

fields.description:
After doing one checkin, subsequent checkins are disabled. This was not the previous behavior, and is frustrating because not only has the behavior changed, but the UI has changed.

Look at the attached screen snapshot. I've got three files selected, and there is a checkin message, but still the Commit button is grayed out.

I contend that nothing about this change in behavior is useful, and it should rightly be called a bug.

Workaround: Exit SourceTree after every checkin, before attempting another checkin.
fields.summary: After making one commit, subsequent commits are disabled

fields.description:
In the new commit screen,
"Push changes immediately to..." option defaults to the origin remote instead of the branch on the forked remote it's tracking.

This was working in 1.8.x, where the tracked branch is selected as the default, and "create a pull request" will initiate a PR against the origin remote.
fields.summary: default push branch is always "origin" instead of actual tracked branch

fields.description:
The new placement of the commit metadata beneath the file list is surprising and strange. 

In 1.8, as you scanned from top-left to bottom-right in the UI there used to be a natural progression from generic to specific, and from broad to detailed:  

- Branches in the sidebar
- commit log in top pane
- selected-commit-specific info in the bottom pane.  

Within the bottom pane, you had a similar logic:
- metadata in the top-left area
- then the list of files beneath that
- then the diff to the right.

The flow was obvious: if A appears below or to the right of B, then A is more specific or detailed than B.  Moving the metadata, which is general, below the file list, which is more specific, breaks up that flow and seems jarring.
fields.summary: Move commit metadata back to above the file list

fields.description:
Hi,

Thanks for SourceTree, which we really appreciate here. Regarding the lastest update for Mac, many things including the side-by-side binary view are great, but we'd like to share a few comments and suggestions.

1. Unifying staged and unstaged files into a single scrollable area hampers productivity for my team.

2. Clicking a checkbox to MOVE files from one area to the other is a regression compared to the previous drag (=MOVE) & drop paradigm that made previous versions of SourceTree the best git experience.

3. Not making "Use staging area" selected by default after update seems a strange choice to me.

4. When "Use staging area" is not selected, staging either lines or hunks checks the "Use staging area" and displays a git error.

5. Losing the separate file and path columns is a real pain...

6. "Stage file" and "Add to index" perform the same action and should probably share the same terminology.

Thanks for your time.

Regards,

Boris Conforty

PS: please check the unstaging process. Most of the time, it hangs.
fields.summary: New streamlined commit experience critiques.

fields.description:
Mac + Windows
All the latest SourceTree versions, including today's update for Mac.

Bug 1
When selecting many commits, I would expect the changes shown to include ALL selected lines, but the last one is not included.

Bug 2
Multi-select with Ctrl (Win) or Command (Mac) shows all changes from first to last (minus one because of Bug 1) instead of only the chosen commits.

Thanks for looking into this.

Regards,

Boris Conforty
fields.summary: Multi commit selection does not include last row commit data

fields.description:
Collating the feedback on 1.9 regarding the positioning of the hunk buttons in the revised diff view.

Several users have been confused because the old diff view had the hunk buttons at the bottom, and now that the diff view has visual containment on files with dividers for hunks, you can misunderstand which hunk (above or below) the buttons relate to. 

So one issue is that there should be a stronger visual association between the button and which hunk it affects, and secondly the argument has been made that the buttons should be at the bottom and not the top, because it's only after you read through a hunk that you decide to stage it, so the bottom of the hunk is the most appropriate place, rather than having to scroll back up to find the button.
fields.summary: Stronger association between hunk buttons & content

fields.description:
This is a holding issue to collate feedback for 1.9 specifically around re-introducing the split pane between staged and unstaged changes.

The argument is that when the file list becomes long, it becomes more difficult to quickly see whether there's anything unstaged because it can be pushed to the bottom, and there's no fixed visual 'anchor' between the two states because of the dynamic flow-based positioning of the dividing line in 1.9.
fields.summary: Re-introduce split pane between staged and unstaged changes

fields.description:
This is a holding issue to collate all the feedback on 1.9 on the specific issue of it being difficult to scan file names out of the combined path & file entries in the 1.9 file status list. 

Users would like the option to have the filename listed separately to the path it's contained in.
fields.summary: Re-introduce the option for separate columns for file/folder in flat file list

fields.description:
When I click the log button on the left of the menu bar, I see a list of changesets in the upper pane.

When I select a changeset in the list, only one affected file is shown in the lower pane. I would expect to see all modified files in the lower pane, as it was in the previous version.
fields.summary: In log view with a changeset selected, only one modified file is shown.

fields.description:
If I do right click over a file, the Custom actions menu seems to have subitems but it doesn't.

Attached screenshot.
fields.summary: "Custom actions" mouse menu is empty

fields.description:
I am happy with the addition of the 'Open in Finder' button, this is an action I was doing quite often.

However I feel the grouping of grey buttons in the toolbar is strange:

!sourcetree-o.png|thumbnail!

'Open in Finder', 'Git-Flow', 'Open in Terminal'. Two of these open external applications, one opens a dialog in SourceTree.

In the very least the 'Open in ...' buttons should be next to each other and the 'Git-Flow' button on a side. Ideally 'Git-Flow' wouldn't be grouped with these other buttons at all. Here is a mockup of a possible solution:

!sourcetree-edit.png|thumbnail!
This places 'Git-Flow' with other git operations and away from the external application launchers.
fields.summary: Reorder toolbar buttons into logical groups

fields.description: !source_tree_pull_request_button.png!
fields.summary: Add Toolbar button for "Create Pull Request..." option
